title: 111_hr5913
content:
The "Text a Tip Act of 2010" establishes a pilot program for texting crime tips. The Attorney General can provide grants to law enforcement agencies for implementing an anonymous tip program via cell phone text messaging. The funds must be used for developing, expanding, or promoting the program, including expenses like salaries, training, technology, and public service promotion. The Federal share of a grant under this Act shall not exceed 75 percent of the program cost and grant amounts should supplement, not supplant, non-Federal funds for activities funded under this Act. The program requirements under this Act include a Federal share not exceeding 75 percent of the program cost, with grant amounts meant to supplement non-Federal funds and not replace them. A texting tip program of a State or local law enforcement agency eligible for a grant under this Act must comply with requirements such as administering the program, stripping incoming text messages of identifying information, ensuring the text tip is untraceable, not replacing existing hotlines, and providing sufficient training for law enforcement agency staff. The law enforcement agency must train personnel to respond to text tips, ensure program compatibility with mobile phone providers, provide tipsters with an unidentifiable code for follow-up information, and include a feature to abort tips. The law enforcement agency must promote the texting program to encourage citizens, especially youth, to participate. No additional fees will be imposed on the tipster's mobile phone, only standard messaging rates apply. To apply for a grant under this Act, a State or local law enforcement agency must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. The application must certify that the program meets the Act's requirements. Additionally, the law enforcement agency must provide reports and evaluations. SEC. 5. REPORTS AND EVALUATIONS.

Recipients of grants under this Act must submit yearly reports to the Attorney General on the effectiveness of activities funded by the grant. The Attorney General, in turn, must submit a yearly report to the Judiciary Committees of the Senate and House of Representatives on the effectiveness of activities under this Act.

SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS.

The term "texting tip program" refers to a program that allows citizens to anonymously text tips to law enforcement agencies to aid in criminal justice by stripping texts of identifying information. "Texting" is defined as sending written messages from a mobile phone. Authorization of appropriations for the Attorney General to carry out the Act is set at $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2011 through 2016.
